info.game_comments: (Sarah: Check out some memorable memorabilia in the Biggest Little State in the Union.  Treasures of Rhode Island, next on Jeopardy!)

(1, 1).clue: "For what is a man profited, if he shall gain the whole world, and lose his own" this

(2, 1).clue: FYI, it's what FYI stands for

(3, 1).clue: In January of 1887 construction began on this for the 1889 Expo in Paris & it's still around

(5, 1).clue: The last line of this classic song is "And crown thy good with brotherhood from sea to shining sea!"

(6, 1).clue: In "'Twas the Night before Christmas", there are this many tiny reindeer pulling a miniature sleigh

(1, 2).clue: In Revelation 22:13, Jesus called himself these 2 Greek letters, "the beginning and the end, the first and the last"

(2, 2).clue: Some of my old vinyl records spin at 45 rpm, rpm standing for this

(3, 2).clue: On display at the Osaka Fair in 1970 was a rock from here; that had to be a fair first

(5, 2).clue: In its original Italian, this 1997 film is titled "La Vita e Bella"

(6, 2).clue: That's right, good buddy, this numerical combo means "message received" to CBers

(1, 3).clue: In Acts 19, St. Paul spoke at Ephesus against this goddess whose temple was an ancient wonder

(2, 3).clue: Beat your opponents to the punch by telling us it's what TKO stands for

(3, 3).clue: This entertainer and future centenarian celebrated his 79th birthday at the 1982 Knoxville Fair

(5, 3).clue: Title woman the unhappy seeker heard here is looking forTell her I'm sorryTell her I need my baby
(5, 3).correct response: "The Most Beautiful Girl In The World"

(6, 3).clue: In the 1840s, this slogan was used by U.S. expansionists in the "fight" over the Oregon border

(1, 4).clue: Jesus told him that "before the cock crow twice, thou shalt deny me thrice"

(2, 4).clue: MP can either be a Member of Parliament or this job in the Army

(3, 4).clue: This author helped kick off construction for the 1904 fair in St. Louis, but declined to have a day named for him

(5, 4).clue: Seen on CBS, this soap opera premiered in 1987

(6, 4).clue: Total number of dots on one standard die

(1, 5).clue: This "Beloved Physician" is thought to be the only Gentile contributor to the New Testament

(2, 5).clue: Abbreviated A.I.M., this advocacy group has been called the "Red Man's Great International Warrior Society"

(3, 5).clue: The 1964 World's Fair celebrated this Duke's taking control of New Amsterdam in 1664

(5, 5).clue: BBW, the publication that bills itself as "The Original Magazine for Plus-Size Women", stands for this

(6, 5).clue: Number of months in a semicentennial

(1, 1).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew shows a scale model of a building.)  The artwork here depicts a Newport, Rhode Island landmark, the oldest one of these houses of worship in the United States

(2, 1).clue: Created by Jack Kirby & Stan Lee, this superhero's human form is Dr. Bruce Banner

(3, 1).clue: 1 of the 2 Irishmen to win a Nobel Prize for Literature in the 1920s
(3, 1).correct response: (1 of) William Butler Yeats or George Bernard Shaw

(4, 1).clue: It's Frosty the Snowman's type of pipe; we hope the smoke doesn't get into his button nose & two eyes made out of coal

(5, 1).clue: Closest to the planet, it shares its name with a pipe-playing Greek god

(6, 1).clue: Send a paper message by phone; lose an "X" & you're left with a musical tone

(1, 2).clue: Built in 1828 & now a national landmark, The Arcade in this city is the oldest indoor shopping mall in the U.S.

(3, 2).clue: Adam Sisman won a National Book Critics Circle Award for his biography of this biographer of Dr. Johnson

(4, 2).clue: From the Greek for "rough", it's your windpipe

(5, 2).clue: The second-largest moon of Saturn or the second-billed female on "Cheers"

(6, 2).clue: This mythological river in Hades, lacking the "X", becomes a home for pigs

(1, 3).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew reports from Providence, Rhode Island.)  The original deed for the land that became Rhode Island was signed by chiefs of this tribe, with the marks of an arrow & a canoe

(3, 3).clue: In 1995 a Pen/Faulkner Award fell upon David Guterson for his "Snow Falling on" these

(4, 3).clue: This plant seen here takes its name from its resemblance to a part of a musical instrument

(5, 3).clue: You'd expect to find Jacques Cousteau riding on this moon of Saturn

(6, 3).clue: Losing its "x" this heat-resistant glassware becomes a funeral conflagration

(1, 4).clue: The Brunonian, which debuted in 1829, was a literary periodical published by this university

(3, 4).clue: The list of Booker Prize winners includes Thomas Keneally for this in 1982

(4, 4).clue: The official flag of this U.S. state bears an olive branch & a peace pipe

(5, 4).clue: After Phoebe was discovered in 1898, the next one was found in 1966 & named for this 2-faced god

(6, 4).clue: Without its "x" this state of constant change gets sick

(1, 5).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from Providence, Rhode Island.)  I'm wielding the sword of this "colorful" Rhode Island general, one of the greatest leaders of the Revolutionary War

(2, 5).clue: With the aid of a magical walking stick, frail & lame Dr. Donald Blake is transformed into this Teutonic superhero

(3, 5).clue: Since 1949, 1 of the 3 Roberts to win the Bollingen Prize in Poetry from Yale
(3, 5).correct response: Robert Frost (Robert Penn Warren or Robert Creeley)

(4, 5).clue: The image of a pipe entitled "This is Not a Pipe" was done by this surrealist

(5, 5).clue: Dione was discovered by this astronomer in 1684; mind the gap, please

(6, 5).clue: If you reach this pinnacle & lose an "X" you become a primate

(0, 0).clue: In honor of the 400th anniv. of his birth, in 1964 he became the first English commoner to appear on a British stamp
